newsitem.title: SPAIN: Telefonica Q1 profit seen as brisk as 1996.
newsitem.headline: Telefonica Q1 profit seen as brisk as 1996.

text.p: Spanish telecommunications giant Telefonica should be able to maintain a brisk 20 percent growth rate in both first quarter and 1997 full-year earnings, analysts said on Friday.
Profit for the January to March period is expected to come in at around 28.9 billion pesetas versus 24.08 billion in the first quarter last year.
"We expect net profit to be boosted by around 20 percent, after showing the same rate one year earlier," an Madrid based analysts said.
But analysts warned that Telefonica's depreciation and provisions policy will make a difference, and may be more cautious than usual.
Analysts said new Spanish rules allowing companies to update the value of their fixed assets, effective since the end of 1996, gives companies huge scope to lift depreciation levels.
Telefonica may also decide to bolster provisions aiming to provide incentives for early retirements.
At the end of April Telefonica said it had offered a new package for early retirement, reducing the minimum age to 55 years from 57.
The firm, one of Spain's biggest employers, has around 70,000 staff and expects to cut that level by 11,000 by 2001.
But analysts were confident about its ability to produce earnings, and even a lower rate of growth in the first quarter would not change their expectations of 20 percent growth for the whole year.
"Telefonica is a money machine. (Chairman) Juan Villalonga said clearly the firm's main target is to produce profits and to increase value for shareholders," said one analyst.
During the first four months of this year alone Telefonica shares have gained 30 percent to a new all-time high on Friday of 3,940 pesetas.
Recently Villalonga told a group of investors he expects group profit to rise 60 percent in the next three years.
Analysts are expecting revenues in the first quarter of 1997 to swell 15.5 percent to 515.4 billion pesetas, while ordinary margin is seen climbing 14.8 percent to 133.4 billion pesetas.
More business in both basic and mobile phone services was seen compensating for cuts in international tariffs since the end of 1996, experts said.
But the downtrend in rates for international and domestic phone calls is one of the few question marks hanging over the Telefonica's future.
"The first quarter this year is going to be the best in terms of operating results. Later in the year further tariff cuts will have more obvious weight," one analyst said.
In mid-March Telefonica cut international tariffs by 8.8 percent. Domestic long distance phone calls fell five percent in April, and are expected to be fall another five percent in July.
The other uncertainty is how the market will evaluate the recently-announced deal with British Telecom and MCI Corp, and analysts believe it is still too early to say.
